sentences.sentence: By Christopher KeeferIn a move likely unnoticed by most Ontarians, the province has inched closer toward a decade-defining victory of energy policy.

Last week, Ontario Power Generation(https://financialpost.com/tag/pickering-nuclear-generating-station/) submitted an application to the Canadian Nuclear Safety Commission (CNSC) to extend the life of the Pickering nuclear generating station(https://financialpost.com/tag/pickering-nuclear-generating-station/) until the fall of 2026.The plan had been for the plant to close at the end of 2025.
But an extra nine months of affordable, low-carbon electricity from the station will benefit Ontarians.

And the bigger news is that the reprieve could pave the way to a full refurbishment that would protect Ontario's domestic supply of clean electricity and high-quality jobs for decades to come.Operating through 2026 would allow skilled refurbishment workers and OPG project managers currently redoing the Darlington Nuclear Station to switch over to Pickering after the Darlington project wraps up that same year.

Meanwhile, the Pickering station would be able to generate extra revenue from the extension, keeping up employment and helping to offset the cost of refurbishment planning.A year ago, our organization released a report that built the case for refurbishing Pickering's four newest reactors ("the B side").
Soon after, the province announced its support for Pickering's continued operation.Keeping the plant running makes sense from a cost perspective.

Refurbishments at Ontario's two other nuclear plants, which are proceeding ahead of schedule, are costing only half the U.S. Energy Information Administration's estimates for what brand new nuclear capacity costs.

Using existing equipment, licences, transmission capacity, buildings and other structures saves both time and money.Apart from legacy hydro dams, Ontario's nuclear fleet makes the cheapest electricity(https://financialpost.com/tag/nuclear/) in the province, while abundant natural fuel and a local supply chain shore up our energy security and economy.

With some of the lowest fuel costs of any thermal power plant in the world, revenue from Pickering supports nearly 5,000 high-quality jobs at the plant and thousands more in the surrounding area.The federal and provincial governments have officially recognized the importance of nuclear energy for meeting climate and energy needs(https://financialpost.com/category/commodities/energy/renewables/).
Even so, development and licensing of a new site can take years.

The Pickering site, which is ideally positioned to supply the Greater Toronto Area with zero-carbon electricity around the clock, is licensed for over 3,000 MW of nuclear capacity - though the operating licences will have to be renewed, as they have been for the refurbished units have been at Bruce and Darlington.With the rise of electric vehicles (EVs) and new industrial processes, electricity demand is on the rise in Ontario.
If each of Ontario's roughly seven million light vehicles, almost all of which are gas- or diesel-powered, were replaced by EVs, Pickering's current capacity could cover their charging needs.
Refurbishing Pickering B would preserve two-thirds of that capacity, enough to keep around 4.5 million EVs charged.
It would be foolish to shut down such a large clean-energy asset in the middle of an electrocution push.Refurbishing Pickering should be more than feasible.
Under current plans the four "A side units," which are the oldest reactors in Ontario, will begin decommissioning in 2024.
But the four "B side units" whose refurbishment OPG is exploring are the same age as those currently being refurbished (one or two at a time) at the Bruce nuclear generating station.

The Bruce units awaiting refurbishment are running better than ever, having several times broken site records for electricity production over the last decade.Plans to refurbish Pickering were paused in 2009 to spare resources for work at Darlington.

Now that Ontario has entered its first energy crunch in decades, and refurbishments at Darlington will be wrapping up, the rationale for moving refurbishment workers to Pickering is stronger than ever.As an enabler of refurbishment, the extension of Pickering's life would be a victory for Canadians.

Closing Pickering not only would cause carbon emissions to spike as gas takes its place, it would also damage, perhaps irreversibly, Ontario's energy security, economic diversity and broad expertise in the important field of nuclear energy.Will the Liberals adopt bill discouraging fossil fuel investment?

(https://financialpost.com/opinion/liberals-adopt-unhinged-senate-bill-deterring-fossil-fuel-investment)Net zero's march to impoverishment(https://financialpost.com/opinion/net-zero-impoverishment-how-lower-gdp-opportunity)Net zero plans, slower growth and trade wars coming soon(https://financialpost.com/opinion/net-zero-plans-slower-growth-trade-wars-economy)Nuclear's value as a non-fossil fuel energy source is becoming a matter of global consensus.
By refurbishing Pickering, Canada would strengthen its clean-energy leadership and serve as a role model for other countries.OPG is currently studying the feasibility of refurbishing Pickering.

If the findings are positive, Ontario's energy future will be a great deal brighter.Chris Keefer is an ER physician practicing in Toronto and president of Canadians for Nuclear Energy, a non-profit independent of industry.
An unpaid volunteer, he receives no income from the nuclear industry.
@COPYRIGHT=© 2023 Postmedia Network Inc. All rights reserved.

documents.result_message: Our detector is highly confident that the text is written entirely by a human.
